hint: File Transfer Protocol Data Channel - Think '20' files being transferred
File Transfer Protocol Control Channel - '21' is one more than 20, handles FTP commands
Secure Shell - '22' looks like a secure tunnel
Telnet (unencrypted remote access) - '23' comes right after SSH (not secure!)
Simple Mail Transfer Protocol - '25' letters in the mail
Domain Name System - '53' like finding an address in a phonebook
DHCP Server - '67' is when the server gives out IP addresses
DHCP Client - '68' is when the client receives an IP address
Trivial File Transfer Protocol - '69' is a simplified version of FTP
Hypertext Transfer Protocol - '80' for web browsing
Kerberos Authentication - '88' looks like a key for authentication
Post Office Protocol v3 - '110' for receiving email
Network News Transfer Protocol - '119' for news groups
Network Time Protocol - '123' like counting time
Remote Procedure Call - '135' for Windows communication
NetBIOS - Range '137-139' for Windows networking
Internet Message Access Protocol - '143' for advanced email retrieval
Simple Network Management Protocol - '161' for network monitoring
SNMP Trap - '162' receives alerts from SNMP devices
Lightweight Directory Access Protocol - '389' for directory services
HTTP Secure - '443' for encrypted web browsing (think padlock icon)
Server Message Block - '445' for file sharing in Windows
Kerberos Password Change - '464' to reset your Kerberos password
SMTP Secure - '465' for encrypted email sending
Syslog - '514' for system logging
LDAP Secure - '636' for encrypted directory access
IMAP Secure - '993' for secure email retrieval
POP3 Secure - '995' for secure email receiving
Microsoft SQL Server - '1433' for database connections
Oracle Database - '1521' for Oracle database connections
Remote Desktop Protocol - '3389' for remote Windows access
Session Initiation Protocol - '5060' for VoIP calls
SIP over TLS - '5061' for secure VoIP
Windows Remote Management - '5985' for HTTP remote management
Windows Remote Management Secure - '5986' for HTTPS remote management
HTTP Alternate - '8080' is commonly used as an alternative to port 80
